docs.snippet: By the time he lifted the ropes to welcome Vernon Forrest into the ring, Ricardo Mayorga had not smoked a cigarette in six weeks. He trained hard, promising to deliver the big right hand that would bring prosperity to his family in Nicaragua.    W...
docs.lead_paragraph: By the time he lifted the ropes to welcome Vernon Forrest into the ring, Ricardo Mayorga had not smoked a cigarette in six weeks. He trained hard, promising to deliver the big right hand that would bring prosperity to his family in Nicaragua. When it came -- a crushing right hand to Forrest's temple with less than a minute remaining in the third round of their welterweight unification fight -- Mayorga, a heavy underdog, lighted a victory cigarette in the ring and kissed his right biceps Saturday night.
docs.abstract: World Boxing Assn champion Ricardo Mayorga scores third-round technical knockout over previously undefeated World Boxing Council champion Vernon Forrest to capture Forrest's title in welterweight unification bout; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Syracuse withstood some woeful shooting yesterday because Miami shot even worse.     The Orangemen shot 37 percent but they shut out the Hurricanes in the final 8 minutes 38 seconds, scoring the game's final 9 points to win, 54-49, in Coral Gables...
docs.lead_paragraph: Syracuse withstood some woeful shooting yesterday because Miami shot even worse. The Orangemen shot 37 percent but they shut out the Hurricanes in the final 8 minutes 38 seconds, scoring the game's final 9 points to win, 54-49, in Coral Gables, Fla.

docs.snippet: Norman Panama, whose screenwriting and directing career stretched from 1930's radio sketches to 1970's satires of sexual liberation and who, with Melvin Frank, created one of Hollywood's most durable and celebrated comedy writing teams, died Jan. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Norman Panama, whose screenwriting and directing career stretched from 1930's radio sketches to 1970's satires of sexual liberation and who, with Melvin Frank, created one of Hollywood's most durable and celebrated comedy writing teams, died Jan. 13 at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 88. Among the writing team's most celebrated works were ''Road to Utopia'' (1945), widely regarded as the best of the Bob Hope-Bing Crosby road comedies and a deconstructionist classic from an era before the term had been coined; ''Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House'' (1948), virtually a time capsule of America's postwar comic mood, with Cary Grant as an advertising executive moving to the suburbs; and ''White Christmas'' (1954), the holiday favorite with Crosby and Danny Kaye, which also had Norman Krasna as a co-writer.
docs.abstract: Norman Panama, screenwriter who wrote many film comedies, dies at age 88 (M)

headline.main: Norman Panama, 88, Half of Duo Who Wrote Many Film Comedies

docs.snippet: Like every degenerate institution that gets more attention than it deserves, haute couture hauls out the violins at the first hint of gloom. As Karl Lagerfeld, who has a longer perspective than most, said, ''Things were overinflated, overexposed, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Like every degenerate institution that gets more attention than it deserves, haute couture hauls out the violins at the first hint of gloom. As Karl Lagerfeld, who has a longer perspective than most, said, ''Things were overinflated, overexposed, overeverything -- and, suddenly, when there's a little problem, things are dead.'' The little problem he was referring to was the absence this season of Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, whose tidy bob and front-row placement seem to reassure designers that they are alive. Miss Wintour occasionally skips a season, but this is a world that reads a lot into the tiniest tremor. And some profess not to feel anything at all: Azzedine Alaïa, who presented his first full-blown collection in a decade, before an audience that included Miuccia Prada and Yohji Yamamoto, refused to invite anyone from Vogue to his show on Thursday, saying that for too long he has been ignored.
docs.abstract: Cathy Horyn reviews haute couture fashion shows in Paris; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Ricardo Mayorga kept talking all week, saying he would drop Vernon Forrest, shake up the welterweight division and put large sums of money in his family's empty pockets in Managua, Nicaragua.    It sounded like the usual prefight hyperbole for a h...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ricardo Mayorga kept talking all week, saying he would drop Vernon Forrest, shake up the welterweight division and put large sums of money in his family's empty pockets in Managua, Nicaragua. It sounded like the usual prefight hyperbole for a heavy underdog, someone needing to sell tickets and interest, until one devastating overhand right to the temple of Forrest in the third round tonight changed the landscape of the division.
docs.abstract: Ricardo Mayorga retains World Boxing Association welterweight title and adds Vernon Forrest's World Boxing Council title in unification bout by scoring third round TKO over Forrest; photo (M)

docs.snippet: IT's just another hollow evening for the bourgeois Parisian couple Paul and Hélène as they wordlessly dress, then rush out to a soirée, in Coline Serreau's movie ''Chaos.'' That is, until a prostitute runs screaming in front of their car, thrus...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT's just another hollow evening for the bourgeois Parisian couple Paul and Hélène as they wordlessly dress, then rush out to a soirée, in Coline Serreau's movie ''Chaos.'' That is, until a prostitute runs screaming in front of their car, thrusting her bloody, terror-struck face against the window. The girl's pimps catch up to her, beat her senseless and leave her for dead on the sidewalk -- and the pair speeds off. ''But what about the girl?'' Hélène asks limply. ''What girl?'' Paul says, and heads to the carwash to remove the inconvenient blood from the windshield. Overcome by guilt, Hélène (Catherine Frot) tracks down the comatose girl (Rachida Brakni) in the hospital and soon after leaves behind her job at a law firm, her indifferent husband (Vincent Lindon) and their ungrateful college-age son to help nurse the stranger back to health. As the film moves between a loopy comedy of the sexes and a girl-power tale about seeking revenge, Ms. Serreau, who wrote and directed, also weaves in the complicated subplot about the girl, a young Algerian who runs away from home to avoid being sold by her father to a businessman and who ends up working the streets. A mishmash of genres, feminist tones and pointed commentary on French-Arab relations, ''Chaos'' which opens on Wednesday in New York before its national release, was seen by more than a million people in France. It also won a César, the French Oscar, for Ms. Brakni as most promising newcomer.
docs.abstract: Kristin Hohenadel article on Coline Serreau's film Chaos, which shows that women of various classes and races suffer same inequality and lack of respect; Serreau comments; photos (M)

headline.main: A Feminist Willing To Be, Well, Incorrect

docs.snippet: New York's nerves run along phone lines, and the beep and click of the well-connected will soon get ratcheted up a notch. Starting Saturday, all New Yorkers will have to dial 11 digits to make local calls, even when calling within the same area co...
docs.lead_paragraph: New York's nerves run along phone lines, and the beep and click of the well-connected will soon get ratcheted up a notch. Starting Saturday, all New Yorkers will have to dial 11 digits to make local calls, even when calling within the same area code. Eleven-digit dialing isn't new, but let's face it, people in Denver don't use the phone they way they do in New York. New York is a city of extreme dialing, where making 100 calls a day is not uncommon. Those four extra digits can add milliseconds -- seconds, if your finger doesn't flex fast enough -- to each call. That's minutes a day, hours a year. Life in the fast lane just got slower.
docs.abstract: Article on reaction of some New York power players to new 11-digit dialing; drawing (M)

headline.main: At the Speed of New York, Even With 11 Digits
headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON SPEED DIAL

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. David B. Skinner, who presided over the merger of New York Hospital and Presbyterian Hospital and served as president until his retirement in 1999, died on Friday. He was 67. The cause was a cerebral hemorrhage, said Myrna Manners, a hospital spokeswoman.

headline.main: Dr. David B. Skinner, 67; Oversaw a Hospital Merger

docs.snippet: Now in its 22nd year, the Black Maria (pronounced ma-RI-uh) Film and Video Festival is an independent nonprofit event that annually exhibits 50 new experimental, documentary, animation and narrative works. It is New Jersey's only Academy Award-qua...
docs.lead_paragraph: Now in its 22nd year, the Black Maria (pronounced ma-RI-uh) Film and Video Festival is an independent nonprofit event that annually exhibits 50 new experimental, documentary, animation and narrative works. It is New Jersey's only Academy Award-qualifying film festival for shorts -- meaning that short films that win at the festival can be entered in competition for the Oscar. The festival takes its name from Thomas Edison's Black Maria Film Studio, built in 1893. The studio, the first in the world, was an oddly shaped structure that could be rotated to allow sunlight to stream continually onto the stage through the open roof.
docs.abstract: Article on Black Maria Film and Video Festival, New Jersey's independent non-profit event that shows 50 new experimental, documentary, animated and narrative works each year; highlights noted (M)

headline.main: The Black Maria: Take Note, Edison

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: BLACK MARIA FILM AND VIDEO FESTIVAL

docs.snippet: ON a rental-car journey through the Strip, with the windows down for the cultural safari, it's impossible to tell the difference between this decadent kingdom in the sand and the National Football League.    Vegas can claim the glittering Mirage h...
docs.lead_paragraph: ON a rental-car journey through the Strip, with the windows down for the cultural safari, it's impossible to tell the difference between this decadent kingdom in the sand and the National Football League. Vegas can claim the glittering Mirage hotel; the N.F.L. claims it seeks racial diversity (another type of mirage). One boasts Elvis impersonators; the other has the owner Al Davis.
docs.abstract: Selena Roberts Sports of The Times column contends that NFL acts hypocritically in opposing sports betting, much of which is legal and even helps expose any fixed games; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Las Vegas and Pro Football Are Perfect Together
